Tenet, the director, and James L. Pavitt, the clandestine services chief, the top two generals who have steered the nation's covert war on terrorism since the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

Ambassador to U.N. Named President Bush named former Senator John C. Danforth, a prominent Republican moderate, to the post of American ambassador to the United Nations.

Iraqi Premier Defends Troops Iraq's new prime minister defended the presence of American and British forces on Iraqi soil and warned that their departure would amount to a ''catastrophe'' for the country.

The top human rights official for the United Nations said that the mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners by American soldiers could constitute a war crime, and he called for the immediate naming of an international figure to oversee the situation.
The Army has opened a criminal investigation into the shooting death of an Iraqi civilian by an American soldier in Kufa. The man was a driver killed during a high-speed chase involving rebels.

American commanders worked out a new cease-fire in southern Iraq with Moktada al-Sadr, the rebel Shiite cleric, agreeing to the second truce in about a month. In Baghdad, five American soldiers were killed in an attack on their convoy.

Pope John Paul II, with President Bush at his side, reiterated his unhappiness over the invasion of Iraq and urged the president to speed the restoration of sovereignty. The pope mixed praise with a diplomatically worded but unmistakable expression of displeasure with the war and its aftermath.

Algeria Detains Terror Suspect Algerian forces took custody of a man believed to be one of North Africa's most powerful Islamic terrorists. He is wanted in connection with many crimes, including his suspected role in the killing of 43 Algerian soldiers and the kidnapping of 32 European hostages, both last year.

Sharon Fires Cabinet Ministers Prime Minister Ariel Sharon fired two hard-line conservative ministers in a risky move that should give him a cabinet majority for his Gaza withdrawal plan, but which could also break apart his right-wing coalition government. Neither minister agreed to go graciously.

Distress Over U.S. Troops The report that thousands of American troops based in Germany and elsewhere in Europe will likely be redeployed did not come as a surprise in Europe, but it has enhanced deep worries that the plans would widely be seen as a sign of a weakened American engagement in Europe.

Questioning of Cheney Is Said to Have Taken Place Vice President Dick Cheney has been interviewed by federal prosecutors who asked whether he knew of anyone at the White House who improperly disclosed the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer, people who have been involved in official discussions about the case said.

Spain Objects to U.S. Methods Spanish law enforcement officials involved in the investigation of the Madrid bombing are challenging key aspects of the American version of events, describing F.B.I. officials as rejecting evidence that they had wrongly arrested a Portland, Ore., lawyer in the case.

California Coast Deal Reached The State of California and the owners of the 82,000-acre Hearst Ranch announced a tentative deal to protect much of the scenic property on California's central coast from any future development.

Charities to Profit From Death Caroline Rose Hunt, the 81-year-old oil heiress who built a second fortune in hotels and resorts, has joined groups of other elderly, wealthy donors who have allowed insurance companies, hedge funds and other investors to insure their lives in exchange for a promise that part of the death benefits will flow to their favorite charities.

Candidate Pays Herself to Run Stephanie Herseth, who won a seat in the House this week, is the first successful candidate to pay herself a salary to run for Congress. Ms. Herseth capitalized on changes to campaign finance rules, which allow candidates to pay themselves a wage from their campaign treasury.

American P.O.W.'s Lose Award A federal appeals court in Washington threw out an award of almost $1 billion won last year by 17 former American prisoners of war for abuse they suffered in Iraq during the Persian Gulf war of 1991.

Change Proposed for Anthem A psychiatrist from California wants to lower the key of the national anthem from B flat to G major. He argues that the simple change would make the anthem accessible to even the tonally challenged.

Officials Urge a Review Of Suffolk's E.M.S. System Critics say it is time to re-examine Suffolk County's emergency response network. The council that monitors it is pushing for big improvements and greater oversight, and emergency medical technicians are venting their frustrations.

Environmental Law Setback A New York judge threw out the state's tough new acid rain rules on a technicality, providing a reprieve to owners of 10 old coal-fired power plants and derailing, at least temporarily, measures that were to have been a high point of Governor Pataki's environmental record.

New Convention Security A top New York police officer defended plans to use four-sided barricades to control demonstrators at the Republican National Convention, saying the police want to keep streets open to allow for an emergency evacuation of the area.

School Officials Suspended The inquiry into financial wrongdoing at a Long Island school district has widened with the suspension of two employees, including the superintendent, and district officials have said that both employees were linked to companies that had billed the district.

A Resignation in Protest Kenneth Maxwell, the chief Latin American expert at the Council on Foreign Relations, quit as a protest, accusing the council of stifling debate on American intervention in Chile during the 1970's as a result of pressure from former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger.
Employers Increase Jobs Employers added 248,000 workers in May, while the unemployment rate remained at 5.6 percent, unchanged from April.

Phone Competition Ruling A federal appeals court rejected a request by the Federal Communications Commission and the nation's two largest long-distance telephone providers to extend regulations that give the companies discounts for leasing the network equipment of the four Bell operating companies.
Ex-Chairman Leaves Company The former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, Sanjay Kumar, cut all ties to the company as a federal criminal investigation enters its final stages.

Salesforce Offering Delayed Salesforce.com, which helps sales people track customers and prospective clients, said it might buy back shares it planned to sell in an initial offering if the company is found guilty of violating federal rules.
